newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: OPPOSITION DENIES COALITION CLAIMS ON BY-ELECTION
The Federal Opposition has denied Coalition claims that the weekend Liberal by-election win in the Sydney seat of Lindsay was a vote for the partial sale of Telstra and Industrial Relations reforms.
Opposition leader, Kim Beazley, has told Radio National, that Government difficulties in getting the legislation through the upper house are the fault of the Coalition Senators.
Federal Government Senate leader, Robert Hill, says the Government can claim the Lindsay result as an endorsement of its mandate.
Senator Hill has urged the minor parties and Opposition to let the partial Telstra sale and industrial reforms get passed.
Australian Democrats Senate Whip, Vicki Bourne, says her Party also has a mandate, and it includes opposing the sale of Telstra.
HARRADINE REJECTS REAFFIRMING OF MANDATE
Tasmania's Independent Senator, Brian Harradine, says the Senate should not become a rubber stamp because of the Lindsay by-election result.
John Howard says the by-election result is a message to those opposed to the government's reforms to get out of the way.
But Senator Harradine has rejected the Prime Minister's claim the by-election reaffirms the Coalition's mandate.
And he says the outcome of the by-election won't influence his vote on the partial sale of Telstra.
He's pressuring the government to accept his preference shares proposal, saying he would be loathe to support the sale of a natural monopoly that could not be undone by a future government.
PASSIVE SMOKING SAID TO CAUSE PROBLEMS FOR CHILDREN
A new study has found that people who smoke at home are adversely affecting the health of their children.
An Australian Medical Association seminar in Canberra on passive smoking has heard that more than 17,000 children each year require treatment for bronchitis because their parents smoke.
Sydney University lecturer Jennifer Peat, says a further 50,000 children each year develop wheezing because they're passive smokers.
Dr Peat says the risk of infants being hospitalised for respiratory illness is double when compared to those living in a smoke free zone.
She says research shows that almost 30 per cent of children have a parent who smokes in the house.
PM CALLED ON TO STOP PRIVATE MEMBERS BILL
Northern Territory Attorney-General Denis Burke says the Prime Minister must now get involved in putting a stop to a Private Members bill to quash the Territory's voluntary euthanasia law.
A weekend Liberal Party conference passed a motion supporting the Territory's right to pass laws uninhibited by Federal Parliament.
Mr Burke says he feels there's a growing mood within the Liberal Party that euthanasia should be debated separately, and not caught up in the issue of Territory rights.
MILITARY POLICE INVOVEMENT IN ARRESTS QUESTIONED
Questions are being raised over the arrests of more than 60 people at a Brisbane music festival on Saturday night.
The Australian Democrats want to know how military police became involved in the arrests at the 4ZZZ community radio station's market day at Musgrave Park.
Democrats Youth Affairs spokeswoman, Natasha Stott Despoja says both she and defence spokesman John Woodley are calling on the Queensland government to explain the police actions.
It's believed riot shields and batons were used on festival goers.
The Council for Civil Liberties wants the Criminal Justice Commission to look into the arrests.
The Council's Terry O'Gorman says the involvement of both State and military police appears to be a major exercise in overkill.
BLACKHAWK INQUIRY MOVES TO NORTH QUEENSLAND
The military Board of Inquiry into the deaths of 18 servicemen in a Blackhawk helicopter accident continues in Townsville today after three and a half weeks of hearing evidence in Perth.
The accident happened near Townsville during night training exercises on June the 12th.
The Inquiry has already heard evidence from 54 witnesses, including soldiers, aircrew, experts and investigators, and will move to Sydney after the Townsville hearings.
President of the Board of Inquiry, Brigadier Paul O'Sullivan is confident the Inquiry report will be completed by the end of December.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
"It doesn't look like it's going up. The likelihood is that it's going down," said Adrian Haylor, technical analyst at Sucden.
"But we are near support so it might hold," Haylor added.
London futures tumbled last week from a high of $1,480 as players shrugged off bullish crop news and focused mainly on looming supplies from Central America.
The latest crop news emerged from El Salvador, where national coffee investigators said some five percent of the estimated coffee crop would be lost because of prolonged rains this year.
Earlier last week, Costa Rica said its crop would suffer large losses after torrential rains from Hurricane Lili.
But brokers dismissed such bullish scenarios.
"It sounds to us as if the producers in El Salvador and Costa Rica are trying to talk the price up by whatever means," said brokers GNI in their daily commentary.
"More likely the coffee harvest will be hampered due to the loss of infrastructure washed away by the rains -- particularly in Nicaragua," it said.
Tanzania, meanwhile, has announced plans to double coffee production to an estimated 100,000 tonnes by 2000.
Sucden's Haylor pegged support basis January at $1,380 and $1,350. Moving averages were bearish while the RSI was still not oversold and there was room for further losses.
Resistance was seen at $1,415 and $1,450.
--Clelia Oziel, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8072
